description.narrative:
Due to its geographic location, Mozambique is highly vulnerable to erratic weather patterns and natural disasters, and as a result the country is exposed to extreme weather events such as floods, droughts, cyclones, cholera and earthquakes. In addition to that, Mozambique is experiencing challenges with respect to climate change. Recently, Mozambique has faced since 2014 a severe drought in Southern and Central region of the country affecting approximately 1.5 million people in Tete, Sofala, Gaza, Inhambane and Maputo Provinces. Due to seriousness of the situation the Government activated institutional red alert seeking for donors to mobilize additional resources and expand their efforts on response actions. In 2016 -17, Oxfam in Mozambique as a member of the COSACA Humanitarian consortium (Concern, Oxfam, Save the Children and Care) responded to the crisis in terms of immediate life-saving and life-sustainingactivities through provision of essential food and seed commodities, livelihoods, and WASH activities.
However, food insecurity ischronic in these areas and the partner proposed for this project (The Association Friends of Youth in Govuro -AJOAGO) is involvedin such emergency responses with Oxfam, local authorities and other INGOs regularly.There is need to assist the partner in developing and promoting innovative water technology that enables more effective livestock production, proactively reduce the impact of the chronic food insecurity in a sustainable manner and reduces the emission ofGreenhouse Gas (GHG). Livestock represents a major resource in which there has not been any significant or appropriately targeted support to make it part of the food security strategy of the region. Cattle and small ruminants are a major source of incomeand food for poor rural households in the targeted area.
The last emergency response ended in June 2017, however in Govuro district of Inhambane province despite reaching 2722 households (HHs) with food assistance and seeds, there is still a need to assist with the recovery of HHs with livestock by provision of WASH for Livelihoods.
Govuro has approximately 180 cattle breeders with more than 3,600 cattle in three communities. With this project we are looking to address the need to ensure that thereis a sustainable water source for two of the locations (another funding source will support the third location).
Against the background of chronic food insecurity in this region and recurrent emergency responses by Oxfam and its partners, the aim of the project is: To expand options for food security by harnessing the potential of already existing livestock production in the area. This is achieved by introducing and promoting innovative and climate smart technology for ensuring sustainable access to water for livestock production.
